newsitem.title: UK: Consortium launches multi-function smart card.
newsitem.headline: Consortium launches multi-function smart card.

text.p: A group of silicon chip makers and smartcard companies led by electronic purse company Mondex International on Thursday launched a new high-security operating system for smartcards that allows the cards to be multi-functional.
In a related move, MasterCard International - which has over 400 million cards in issue - said it has chosen the new system, called MULTOS, as its chip card platform.

The companies in the MULTOS consortium are Dai Nippon Printing, Gemplus (the world's leading producer of plastic and smartcards), Hitachi, Keycorp, MasterCard International, Mondex International, Motorola and Siemens.
The consortium, known as MAOSCO (pronounced Mouseco), will have the aim of establishing MULTOS as an industry standard and manage the card's development.
In a statement, MAOSCO said that MULTOS is compatible with all existing international standards and will permit products from different industries to co-exist on the same card.

The card could carry a GSM mobile phone, credit and debit products, retailer loyalty schemes as well as an electronic purse, train or air tickets, club memberships and access to workplaces and computers.
The system will be flexible so that users can load products on the card when they need them and unload them when they have finished.
Typically, MULTOS holders will be able to customise their card by downloading software to enable applications via the Internet or a telephone line.
MULTOS will be the first card where the applications will be kept totally separate and secure by 'firewalls' guaranteeing the security and integrity of each application and the overall card.
MULTOS spokesman Nick Habgood told Reuters that the smartcard technology could have myriad applications especially when laid together with burgeoning Internet technology.
Habgood said the cards will be available from the first quarter of 1998.
"MULTOS is to the smartcard industry what Windows (the PC operating system developed by Microsoft) was to the PC," Habgood said.
